fields.descriptive_line: Portrait miniature of an unknown man, watercolour on vellum, painted by Samuel Cooper, 1657.
fields.physical_description:
Portrait, head and shoulders, turned to and looking to right.  Features firmly hatched in brown and sanguine, with a little blue-grey shadow, on a thick warm carnation ground; hair in pale brown wash, hatched with darker colour and heightened with gouache; the costume washed and hatched in gouache with touches of gold for the buttons; background a dark grey wash, lightened with grey hatches to the right of the sitter's head; on vellum put down on pasteboard. 

<u>Frame</u>
Nineteenth-century copper-gilt rim of V-section forming a rebate for the glass at the front; the back closed by a toothed copper strip.
fields.title: An Unknown Man
fields.materials_techniques: Watercolour on vellum put down on pasteboard
fields.marks:
'SC. [interlaced] 1657'
 'Saml. Cooper /by Himself/ dated 1657/ On Card prepared as/Ass's skin/ £ 100'
 '41.'
fields.exhibition_history: Samuel Cooper and his Contemporaries (National Portrait Gallery 1974-1974)
fields.bibliography: Murdoch, John. Seventeenth-century English Miniatures in the collection of the Victoria and Albert Museum. London: The Stationery Office, 1997. Cat.77, pp.143-144. Full Citation: “77 Unknown Man 1657 D90 Oval 71 x 57mm Features firmly hatched in brown and sanguine, with a little blue-grey shadow, on a thick warm carnation ground; hair in pale brown wash, hatched with darker colour and heightened with gouache; the costume washed and hatched in gouache with touches of gold for the buttons; background a dark grey wash, lightened with grey hatches to the right of the sitter's head; on vellum put down on pasteboard. Condition: Areas of heavy zinc-white overpainting on forehead and left of face; retouch on the collar; some marginal abrasions. Signed: In gold, centre right: SC. [interlaced] 1657. Inscribed in ink on the back: Saml. Cooper /by Himself/ dated 1657/ On Card prepared as/Ass's skin/ £ 100. An earlier inscription, perhaps by the same hand, has been rubbed deeply out of the card leaving some indecipherable parts of letters. Also inscribed in graphite: 41. Frame: Nineteenth-century copper-gilt rim of V-section forming a rebate for the glass at the front; the back closed by a toothed copper strip. Provenance: The Revd Alexander Dyce, by whom bequeathed to the Museum, 1869. Exhibited: NPG 1974, no. 1 (as self-portrait", qualified as too young to be Cooper, and the image quite unlike the pastel, D91). Literature: Redgrave 1874, p. 8 (self-portrait); Foster 1896, p. 211; Foster 1898, pl. xix; Foster 1903, vol. I, p. 52; Williamson 1904, vol. I, p. 72, pl. xliii, fig. 3; Catalogue of Miniatures, 1908, p. 8 (self-portrait on card); Holmes 1906, p. 298, repro. facing p. 295, no. 2 (self-portrait); Goulding 1914-15, p. 126 (sceptically as' stated' to be a self- portrait); Foster 1914-16, vol. I, p. 29, pl. xxvii, no. 61 (self-portrait) and vol. Il, p. 24, no. 106; Williamson 1921, p. 66 (on the so-called Cooper self-portraits); Long 1929, p. 88; Long 1930, p. 12 (as self-portrait on vellum on card); Piper 1963, p. 82 ('not altogether satisfactory as a self-portrait when compared with' the type based on D91); Foskett 1974, p. 13 (supposed self-portrait), p. 38 (appearing to defend it as a self-portrait and referring to the inscription as eighteenth-century), p. 115 (self-portrait); Millar 1974, p. 346 (referring to 'wise doubts' about the identification); Summary Catalogue, 1981, p. 10 ('said to be a self-portrait'). The only evidence for the identification as a self-portrait is the inscription on the back of the card. Long considered this to be eighteenth-century, and accepted it as representing an authoritatively traditional identification. Three points, however, are worth making: 1 The inscription, whatever its date, has been tampered with and is thus prima facie suspect. 2 The handwriting, the consistent use of the short's' (even in 'ass's') and the pound sign £, together with the very high price paid for the miniature, suggest a date at the earliest in the mid-nineteenth century. 3 The use of unstiffened card for the mounting of the vellum is rare in Cooper's practice in the 1650s.The likelihood is that the vellum was remounted at the time of the repainting of the face, which was carried out in zinc-based white (not introduced until c. 1792) by a restorer of considerable skill. Until the late 1940s there was, apart from Goulding's discreet scepticism, a consensus enforced by Long's prestige to give this miniature the benefit of any doubt occasioned by comparison of it with the more credible pastel drawing (D91). In March 1947 Graham Reynolds expressed doubt, (1) repeating it a year later in correspondence about the pastel with David Piper. Piper publicly agreed with Reynolds (2) and subsequent writers have added their endorsement, occasionally with some confusion. The pastel does indeed have a very long tradition identifying it as an image of Cooper; it goes back to the Graham sale.(3) Graham was the most important early biographer of Cooper. (4) His belief in the pastel is partly supported by the statement of Cooper's sister-in-law that it was 'not very like, not by Cooper himself but by ... Jackson’; and further supported by Vertue's interesting statement that 'Jackson' was a relation of Cooper. As Mary Edmond has suggested, 'Jackson’ must be 'Jack's son', i.e., Cooper's cousin, the younger Hoskins. (5) Whoever it is by, however, the identification is relatively secure, and by comparison with it the miniature is clearly of a different person. The nose especially is different, being hooked in the pastel but long and straight in the miniature. Furthermore, in 1657 Cooper was about forty -nine and the sitter for the miniature seems younger than that. 1 MS note in Museum files. 2 Piper 1963, p. 82. 3 6 March 1711, at Pelletier's in Henrietta Street, lot 48, bt by 'Mr Boyle'. 4 Author of 'A Short Account of the most eminent Painters' (see Graham 1716). 5 'Lord Carleton had a portrait of Cooper in crayons, which Mrs Pope said was not very like ... It was painted by one Jackson, a relation of Cooper, of whom I know nothing more' ,Walpole 1762, vol. Il, pp. 148-9; cited in Edmond 1978-80, p. 112. Walpole's source is Vertue II, p. 41; see also Piper 1963, p. 82.”
fields.credit: Bequeathed by the Reverend Alexander Dyce
fields.history_note: <u>Provenance:</u> The Revd Alexander Dyce, by whom bequeathed to the Museum, 1869. <b>Exhibited:</b> NPG 1974, no. 1 (as self-portrait", qualified as too young to be Cooper, and the image quite unlike the pastel, D91).
